election_record.label: Connecticut 1823 Lieutenant Governor

overview.note: Connecticut law required a majority to elect. David Plant would subsequently be elected by the Connecticut General Assembly.
The 4 votes for Roger M. Sherman in New London County do not appear on the summary sheet of the Original Election Returns and he is listed with 97 total votes.

"We have felt ourselves bound to support Mr. Perkins' nomination because it was made in a manner of all others the most unexceptionable; and had Mr. Plant been nominated in his stead, we should as cheerfully have supported him, though as yet we have been unable to learn what paramount claims the last mentioned gentleman has for the office. We had supposed that this nomination was far more binding on us, than the one made by a few individuals belonging to Hartford, and Middletown. And if such an one is to be disregarded, then in our humble opinion it is high time all nominations were abolished, or that the few persons who caused it to be opposed, were clothed with full powers to make the future nominations for the party. No choice of a Lieut. Governor having been made, it devolves on the legislature to make one." American Mercury (Hartford, CT). April 22, 1823.

"The following canvass of votes for Lieutenant Governor and Secretary in Hartford County, is the best comment on the assertions of the Mercury, that in this quarter, no dissatisfaction of any consequence existed at the nomination of Mr. Perkins, and that the nomination of Mr. Seymour for Secretary, was 'obnoxious to the republicans in this vicinity, where he is best known.' In those towns where but few or not votes were given for Swift or Pitkin, the federalists voted for Perkins." The Times and Hartford Advertiser (Hartford, CT). April 29, 1823.

"Considering the almost unbounded exertions that were made by a few Hotspurs to prevent the election of Mr. Perkins by proclaiming him 'a Hartford Convention federalist,' and by asserting that his nomination was procured by unfair means, it is really a matter of surprize that he obtained as many votes for this office, as the results of the election shows, were given for him. It is in vain to say that the federalists voted for him. He is among the last persons in this state whom this party would ever support for any office. He has done too much in aid of the republican administration to meet with any favor from that quarter." American Mercury (Hartford, CT). May 6, 1823.

sub_unit.name: Sherman
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Sherman.

sub_unit.name: Meriden
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Meriden.

sub_unit.name: Coventry
sub_unit.note: Roger M. Sherman received 1 vote as Roger Sherman.

sub_unit.name: Hampton
sub_unit.note: There were no votes recorded in Hampton.
